Situation1: Their family members have recently emphasized the importance of maintaining long-held customs.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: Officials ask voters with last names A–M to move to a newly opened line, even though the original line is moving faster.
Story:
I stood in the crowded gymnasium, clutching my voter registration card, my stepmother’s words echoing in my mind: “In this family, we do things the right way, the way we always have.” She’d spent the morning reminding me how important it was to honor our traditions, to show respect for rules and customs, especially in public. As a step-child, I always felt the pressure to prove I belonged, to never give anyone a reason to question my place in the family.

Now, an election official called out, “If your last name starts with A through M, please move to the new line on the left.” My last name—my father’s name—put me squarely in that group. But the new line was long and slow, while the original line, where I’d been waiting, was moving quickly. I hesitated, feeling the weight of my stepmother’s expectations to do what’s right, to follow the rules, but also the unspoken family tradition of not making a fuss, of blending in and not drawing attention. My heart pounded as I wrestled with what to do, torn between honoring my family’s values and following the official’s instructions.
